Expectation1: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation1: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: An individual arrives at the church in a state of acute emotional distress seeking immediate spiritual support for a crisis.
Story: I stared at my laptop screen, the code review comments blinking at me like warning lights. “Performance issues—needs refactoring,” my lead had written. I knew the new feature was almost done, but the code wasn’t as clean as it should be. My mind raced with solutions, ways to optimize, to meet the team’s expectations for quality and efficiency. I was about to dive back in when my phone buzzed. It was the church secretary: someone had arrived, desperate, in tears, needing spiritual guidance right now. My heart clenched. As a priest, I was expected to be present, to listen, to offer comfort and hope in moments of crisis. But as a developer, I was expected to deliver reliable, maintainable code—on time. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait. My hands hovered over the keyboard, my mind torn between the urgent needs of a soul in pain and the relentless demands of the code review.
